content.webTitle: European leaders react with caution as Trump falsely claims victory

fields.headline: European leaders react with caution as Trump falsely claims victory
fields.bodyText: European politicians have counselled patience after Donald Trump’s false claim of victory in the US election in the early hours of Wednesday morning, and warned that a drawn-out court battle over the outcome would have disastrous consequences for democracy’s reputation. Many government leaders remained silent, waiting for events to unfold, though the Spanish foreign minister, Arancha González Laya, urged US leaders to allow all the votes to be counted. Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer, the German defence minister, said: “This is a very explosive situation. This is a situation that can lead to a constitutional crisis in the US, as experts are rightly saying. And it is something that must cause us great concern.” Only one leader, the Slovenian prime minister, Janez Janša, jumped the gun by saying it was pretty clear that Trump was the winner, adding that there was no point in the mainstream media denying this fact. By contrast, the EU foreign affairs chief, Josep Borrell, tried to lower the temperature, saying: “The American people have spoken. While we wait for the election result, the EU remains ready to continue building a strong transatlantic partnership, based on our shared values and history.” The failure of Joe Biden, a committed pro-European and multilateralist, to yet secure the predicted resounding win reignited the debate in Europe on whether the US could remain a close partner. Some European leaders have suggested that even if Biden is eventually declared the winner, he would be a weakened president, without a Senate majority and therefore likely to be preoccupied by domestic issues and attacks from a still-vibrant Trump movement. The Bundestag foreign affairs committee chairman, Norbert Röttgen, said Trump had treated Germany as his favourite enemy, and Biden “would want to work with Germany but would also expect a lot from us. As president, Biden would also focus on China and the Indo-Pacific. That would mean Europe would have to take more responsibility.” The German Green leader, Robert Habeck, said: “If Trump wins, the global order will change fundamentally. Europe must unite, otherwise it will no longer play a role internationally.” France’s finance minister, Bruno Le Maire, a leading advocate of greater “strategic autonomy” for Europe, said the US “has not been a friendly partner for the EU. Whether Joe Biden or Trump is chosen by the Americans does not change this strategic fact. The American continent has detached itself from the European continent and it is time for Europeans to assume their responsibilities.” In the UK, Boris Johnson sidestepped calls in parliament from the opposition leader, Keir Starmer, to tell Trump not to interfere in the ballot count, saying: “We don’t comment as the UK government on the democratic processes of our friends and allies.” Other senior Conservatives including the former foreign secretary Jeremy Hunt said it would be calamitous for the democratic cause worldwide if the election ended with the result disputed. Hunt told the BBC: “My biggest worry is that we forget that the US is the leading democracy in the world, and if we end up with a huge argument about process, and people talking about a stolen elections left, right and centre, we are only going to put a smile on the face of people like President Putin and President Xi who will look at their own people and say ‘are you not pleased we have not got any of this mess?’ and that would be an absolute disaster. We must remember that the reputation of democracy across the world is at stake here.” Sir Nigel Sheinwald, a former UK ambassador to Washington, said the issue if Trump won was whether the US continued to underperform on the world stage. He expressed concern the US was so internally divided and had such deep social problems that it would not provide the leadership the world craves. “I fear we will get more of the same or, even worse, an even more unpredictable and inconsistent leader than in the first term,” he said. Vladimir Putin’s allies in Russia expressed satisfaction with the results so far, claiming that previous allegations that Trump’s victory in 2016 was due to Russian interference had been disproved. Konstantin Kosachev, the chair of the upper house Federation Council committee of foreign affairs, said: “[Russia] benefits from any certainty in which the losers won’t need to resort to [claims of] foreign interference. It’s time for America to return to the politics of sanity, in which case we will always support it. It is high time.” Iran, one of the countries that has most at stake in the election owing to Trump’s policy of maximum economic pressure on Tehran, claimed the US was in decline and predicted that Iran would be able to resist. President Hassan Rouhani said the result of the US election was not important for his country’s clerical rulers, but he called on the next US president to respect international treaties and laws.
